questions.question: What is the purpose of the `calc()` function in CSS?
options: It performs calculations to set CSS property values dynamically.
It calculates the size of elements based on viewport dimensions.
It computes color values for gradients.
It is used to determine the positioning of elements.
questions.answer: It performs calculations to set CSS property values dynamically.

questions.question: What does the `will-change` property do in CSS?
options: It hints to the browser which properties are likely to change, enabling optimizations.
It defines which elements should be rendered before others.
It animates an element's changes smoothly.
It specifies the style changes that should occur on user interaction.
questions.answer: It hints to the browser which properties are likely to change, enabling optimizations.

questions.question: How do CSS Grid and Flexbox differ in their layout capabilities?
options: CSS Grid allows two-dimensional layouts, while Flexbox is one-dimensional.
Flexbox is only for horizontal layouts, while Grid is for vertical.
CSS Grid is easier to use for responsive designs than Flexbox.
Flexbox requires a parent container to work, while Grid does not.
questions.answer: CSS Grid allows two-dimensional layouts, while Flexbox is one-dimensional.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CSS custom properties (variables)?
options: They allow the reuse of values throughout the stylesheet and support dynamic changes.
They are used to define fixed styles that cannot be changed.
They improve loading performance by reducing the number of CSS rules.
They replace the need for media queries.
questions.answer: They allow the reuse of values throughout the stylesheet and support dynamic changes.

questions.question: How can the `@supports` rule be used in CSS?
options: It applies styles based on browser support for specific CSS features.
It defines media queries for different screen sizes.
It adds comments to the CSS code.
It allows for importing other stylesheets conditionally.
questions.answer: It applies styles based on browser support for specific CSS features.

questions.question: What is the difference between absolute and relative positioning in CSS?
options: Absolute positioning is relative to the nearest positioned ancestor, while relative positioning is relative to the element's original position.
Relative positioning is relative to the viewport, while absolute positioning is relative to the document flow.
Absolute positioning does not remove the element from the document flow, while relative positioning does.
Relative positioning is only for inline elements, while absolute positioning is for block elements.
questions.answer: Absolute positioning is relative to the nearest positioned ancestor, while relative positioning is relative to the element's original position.

questions.question: How can you create a CSS triangle?
options: By setting the width and height to 0 and using border properties to create a triangle effect.
By using the `clip-path` property.
By utilizing the `transform` property.
By applying a gradient to a square element.
questions.answer: By setting the width and height to 0 and using border properties to create a triangle effect.

questions.question: What does the `object-fit` property do in CSS?
options: It specifies how an element should be resized to fit its container.
It controls the visibility of an element.
It defines how text should be aligned within a container.
It sets the layout of an element based on its content.
questions.answer: It specifies how an element should be resized to fit its container.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the `z-index` property in CSS?
options: It controls the stacking order of positioned elements.
It defines the size of an element.
It sets the transparency of an element.
It changes the layout of an element.
questions.answer: It controls the stacking order of positioned elements.

questions.question: How does the `:nth-child()` selector work in CSS?
options: It selects elements based on their position within a parent element.
It selects elements based on their class or ID.
It applies styles to all children of an element.
It targets elements that match a specific attribute.
questions.answer: It selects elements based on their position within a parent element.
